Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I sat at my desk, the emergency motion for a temporary restraining order spread out before me, the clock ticking louder with every passing minute. As a judge, I knew the gravity of my responsibility—lives could be changed by my decision, and I owed it to everyone involved to review every detail with care. The expectation was clear: analyze the case files thoroughly, no shortcuts, no rushing. But today was also Election Day, and I had promised myself I would vote. The polling station was open all day, and my schedule was light, but now, with this urgent case, I felt the pressure mounting. I glanced at the clock again, calculating how long it would take to drive to the polls and back. My civic duty as a voter tugged at me—I believed in participating, in making my voice heard. Yet, the weight of the case before me pressed down harder. I felt torn, my mind racing between the demands of justice and democracy, knowing that whatever I chose, I would be letting down one part of myself.
